metadata.title: Effects of tin doping level on structure, acidity and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-O<ce:inf loc=post>x</ce:inf> catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO by ammonia

S1381-1169(16)30118-2 10.1016/j.molcata.2016.03.042 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of experimental setup: (1) gas source; (2) mass flow controllers; (3) gas mixer; (4) gas mixer and preheater; (5) steam generator; (6) reactor; (7) tube furnace; (8) gas analyzer. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst with different Ti/Sn ratio. Reaction conditions: [NO]=[NH3]=600ppm, [O2]=6vol.%, GHSV=20000h−1. The total gas flow rate was 833ml/min and Ar as balance gas. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 selectivity of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Reaction conditions: [NO]=[NH3]=600ppm, [O2]=6vol.%, GHSV=20000h−1. The total gas flow rate was 833ml/min and Ar as balance gas. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 X-ray diffraction patterns of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NH3-TPD profiles of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Py-IR spectra of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts after vacuum treatment at 25°C. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Py-IR spectra of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide after vacuum treatment at different temperature. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Reaction scheme of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 SEM micrographs of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 TEM micrographs of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst in the presence of SO2 and H2O. Reaction conditions: [NO]=[NH3]=600ppm, [O2]=6vol.%, [SO2]=300ppm, [H2O]=10vol.%, GHSV=20000h−1. The total gas flow rate was 833ml/min and Ar as balance gas. The temperature was 200 °C. Fig. 13 Fig. 14 FT-IR spectrum curves of the Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst. Fig. 14 Table 1 Summary of the prepared catalysts. Table 1 Sample abbreviations Ti/Ce (in mol) Ti/Sn (in mol) TC 4 – TSC-1 4 16 TSC-2 4 8 TSC-3 4 4 TSC-4 4 2 TSC-5 4 1 Table 2 Specific surface area, Pore volume and average pore size of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalysts. Table 2 Sample SBET/(m2 g−1) Vtotal/(cm3 g−1) Dpore/(nm) TC 100.5 0.23 9.2 TSC-3 97.6 0.17 6.9 Table 3 The quantitative analysis of H2-TPR over the Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalysts. College of Materials Science and Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 PR China Graphical abstract A series of tin-doped Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts were synthesized by sol–gel method and tested for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR). Effects of tin additives on structure, acidity and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-Ox for NH3-SCR of NO were investigated through characterization of N2 adsorption–desorption, H2-TPR, XRD, NH3-TPD and SEM. Results showed that tin additives extended the active temperature window especially toward lower temperatures and the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox (the Ti/Sn is equal to 4) catalyst reached 92% at 200°C. The addition of tin not only inhibit grain growth of CeO2 and TiO2, but also expand unit cell and cause lattice distortion, which are especially beneficial to NH3-SCR. Moreover the introduction of tin also improved redox property significantly and enhance the acidity of catalyst. The anti-sulfur and anti-influence of water performance of catalyst also improved by tin-doped, when injecting 300ppm SO2 and 10vol.% H2O, the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst was still reached 85% at 200 °C. Keywords NOx Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts Selective catalytic reduction Sn-doped Anti-poisoning ability 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is one of the major air pollutants which cause fog and haze, acid rain, photochemical smog. Currently, NOx pollution is getting more serious. Stringent emission regulations, rigorous emission control standards and growing environmental awareness are being imposed or raised to reduce the NOx pollution. Selective Catalytic Reduction method (SCR) has become the most important technology of NOx control because of its high denitration efficiency, selectivity, stability and no by-products generated. The SCR catalyst is the core of the SCR technology. Generally, the maturely commercial catalyst for NH3-SCR of NOx from coal-fired flue gas react and dissolve in the high temperature range of about 310–410°C. The catalyst is relatively effective but the reaction temperature must be higher than 300°C [1–3]. For the part of industrial boiler that flue gas temperature below 300°C, the low-temperature NH3-SCR technology become the most economical choice. However, commercial catalysts are difficult to meet the demand. Therefore, developing highly efficient and stable low-temperature SCR catalysts which can used under the condition of low temperature (<310°C) become the key of low-temperature NH3-SCR technology. Manganese-based oxides catalysts with excellent de-NOx catalytic activity at low-temperature have been attracting wide attention. Long et al. [4] prepared Fe–Mn catalysts, the NO removal rate reached 99% at 120 °C, but the NO removal rate declined rapidly with injecting SO2 and H2O. Roy et al. [5] reported a Ti0.9Mn0.1O2-δ and Ti0.9Mn0.05Fe0.05O2-δ catalyst which prepared by solvent combustion method, active for the selective NO reduction with NH3 at low temperatures and the NO removal rate reached 100% at 140°C, but after injecting SO2, on the surface of the catalyst produces irreversible inactivation. Casapu et al. [6] also prepared a Nb-Containing Mn–Ce catalyst using impregnation method, the NO removal rate reached 99% at 250°C, when inject 1000ppm SO2, NO removal rate quickly fell to about 30%. Despite the Manganese-based oxides catalysts all have highly efficient at low temperature (100–200°C), but existence of SO2 and H2O will cause catalyst poisoning. So, SO2 and H2O poison effect become the bottleneck of low temperature SCR denitration catalyst development, also is the main reason for preventing the practical application of low-temperature catalyst. SnO2 has unique electronic configuration, it could be used as co-catalyst in catalysis [7]. Kung et al. [8,9] prepared a SnO2/Al2O3 catalyst using impregnation method, the catalyst in the water and SO2 conditions still had high activity. Teraoka et al. [10] also confirmed that SnO2 had good thermal stability and hydrothermal stability, could be used for maintaining the denitration activity. Our previous work [11] showed that a representative Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide revealed stable activity for NH3-SCR of NO in the high temperature range of about 310–410°C. In this work, the tin will be doped in Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide to improve the catalytic activity for NH3-SCR of NO at low temperature and improve practical anti-sulfur and anti-influence of water performance ability of Ti-Ce-Ox for NH3-SCR of NO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts were synthesized by sol–gel method. In a typical process, the titanium–tin–cerium composite sols were prepared by solution A and B. The solution A was mixed by dissolving Ti(OC4H9)4 (Shanghai Ling Feng Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR 98%) in CH3CH2OH under continuous stirring for 20min. And, the solution B was made of glacial acetic acid, deionized water and CH3CH2OH. Then, the solution B was added in solution A slowly under continuous stirring for 20min. Lastly, different ratios of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. AR 98%) and SnCl4·4H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., AR 99.5%) were dissolved in AB mixture under vigorous stirring for 30min. The aged gels were obtained by aging of the sols at 80°C for 24h. The aged gels were calcined at 500°C for 2h. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting particles through crushing, grinding and sieving, were made about 40–60mesh powder [12–14]. The preparation catalysts are given in Table 1 . 2.2 Characterization The Micro-morphology of the catalysts were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) using a JEOL model JSM-5900 at 10kV. Transmission electron microscopy is conducted by a JEM-2010 UHR transmission electron microscope (TEM), using a 200kV accelerating voltage. The samples are dispersed inmethanol using an ultrasonicator for 5min and fixed on a carbon-coated copper grid (LC200-Cu, EMS) prior to the TEM analysis.The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter (BJH method) of the catalysts were observed by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms using a surface area analyzer (Micromeritics, 2020M V3.00H) at 77K. And before adsorption experiments, the catalysts were degassed at 350°C under vacuum for 3h. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of catalysts were recorded via a D/MAX-RB X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan), which using Cu Kα radiation. The 2θ scans cover the range of 5–80°, and the accelerating voltage and applied current are 40kV and 40mA, respectively. Total acidity measurement of catalysts were observed by a temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia using an Autochem 2910 (Micromeritics). And before adsorption experiments, the samples were heated to 450°C under a helium flow for 1h and then cooled to 100°C. The ammonia adsorption process was by using a gas stream that containing 10 vol% NH3 in helium (30mlmin−1) for 1h to achieve the adsorption equilibrium. Then the samples were purged with helium for 1h to remove the weakly adsorbed ammonia. Finally ammonia was desorbed in a flow rate of 30mlmin−1 helium from 100°C to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. And desorption of ammonia was monitored online by Thermo ONIX ProLab mass spectrometer. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectrum (Py-IR) measurement was recorded using a Nexus 670 model FT-IR apparatus in a range of 1200–2100cm−1 by accumulating 64 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. The measurement temperature is 22°C, and the humidity is 50%. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was observed on a semiautomatic Micromeritics TPD/TPR 2900 apparatus in a temperature range of 50–800 °C at a heating rate of 5°Cmin−1. Before reduction experiments, the samples were heated to 400°C under an argon and then cooled to 100°C. Reduction performance was recorded by passing a 5%H2 +95%Ar at a flow rate of 50mlmin−1 through the sample around 30mg. 2.3 Measurement of catalytic activity The catalytic performance of catalysts was tested in a fix bed reactor and Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagram of catalyst test unit. In order to simulate real conditions, NO(600ppm), NH3(600ppm), SO2(300ppm) and O2(6vol.%) were mixed as simulated flue gas. The total gas flow rate was 833ml/min and Ar as balance gas. For each catalytic activity test, 2g catalyst was used and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 20000h−1. The inlet concentration of NO and outlet concentration of NO were measured by a gas analyzer (J2KN, Ecom, Germany). The NO conversion of the catalyst (X) was expressed by the Eq. (1): (1) X N O = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % The N2 selectivity of catalysts was calculated by detecting the concentrations of NO, NH3, NO2 and N2O. And the concentrations of NO, NH3, NO2 and N2O were analyzed by an FTIR spectrometer (Nexus 670, Nicolet, USA), which equipped with a 2m multiple-path gas cell. The N2 selectivity of catalysts was expressed by the Eq. (2): (2) η = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t + [ N H 3 ] i n + [ N H 3 ] o u t − [ N O 2 ] o u t − 2 [ N 2 O ] [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t + [ N H 3 ] i n + [ N H 3 ] o u t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of tin additive on catalytic activity for NH3-SCR of NO The NO conversion of the Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts with different Ti/Sn molar ratio were compared under same reaction conditions (NH3/NO=1) as shown in Fig. 2 . It found that tin additives extended the active temperature window and led to the active window of the catalyst toward lower temperatures compared to the Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2, at the temperature range of 100–200 °C, all the catalytic activities of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalysts increased with the reaction temperature increasing. In this stage, the surface activation energy of the catalysts and the kinetic energy of reactive gases had been enhanced with temperature, so the catalytic activities grew greatly during this temperature range. Then, the catalytic activities reached highest activities in the temperature range of 200–350°C and kept stable in this temperature range. Compared with the Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst, the temperature range of highest activities moved to low-temperature 100°C. In this stage, the physical and chemical adsorption could be saturation and the adsorption-desorption of reactants and products was dynamic balance. Therefore, the catalytic activity was relatively stable. When the temperature was higher than 350 °C, because of the oxidation of NH3, the catalytic activities of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst decreased quickly [15]. Compared with the Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst, tin additives improve the catalytic activities in the low temperature of 50–100°C. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 2, the (the Ti/Sn is equal to 4) exhibited highest catalytic performance and the NO conversion efficiency reached 92% at 200°C. We will choose this sample for analysis. As seen in Fig. 2, the catalytic activities performance changed with the amount of tin additive. Generally, the structure, redox and acidity were considered as the main effective factors in the NH3-SCR of NO. So, the effect of tin additives on structure and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst will be discussed by characterization analysis in the following sections. Fig. 3 shows the N2 selectivity of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalyst all exhibited high N2 selectivity, when 100°C. However, with the increase of the temperature, the N2 selectivity decreased slightly to 90% because of the formation of N2O and NO2. Compared with TC catalyst, the TSC-3 had higher N2 selectivity indicating the Sn additives could enhance the N2 selectivity of the Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO. 3.2 XRD analysis Fig. 4 shows the X-ray diffraction patterns of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalysts. It showed Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxides exhibits typical diffraction patterns for the tetragonal system TiO2 and cubic CeO2. And the main crystal phase of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxides is rutile-type SnO2. Moreover, as the ionic radii of Sn4+ (0.069nm) and Ti4+ (0.0605nm), satisfy equation of |(r1 −r2)/r1|×100%<15%, so the SnO2 can react with TiO2 form continuous solid solutions. And the ionic radii of Ce4+ (0.087nm) and Sn4+ (0.069nm), satisfy equation of 15%<|(r1 −r2)/r1 ×100%|<30%, thus the SnO2 can react with CeO2 to form discontinuous solid solutions [16]. The introduction of tin also caused expansion of unit cell as a result of substitution of the Ti4+ by the bigger Sn4+ one (lattice distortion), which favors structural defect formation. The lattice distortion is beneficial to form reactive centers or yield active oxygen species in catalytic reduction of NO [17,18]. Additionally, it could be seen from Fig. 4, the solid-state structure of the TSC-3 complex oxide was coexistence of amorphous and crystal in the phase, and its weak diffraction peak pertaining to matted crystal of CeO2 and TiO2 were able to be found. It showed that TiO2 and CeO2 evenly dispersed and mainly in the presence of an amorphous phase, which indicated that Sn-doped can inhibit their grain growth of CeO2 and TiO2. 3.3 Specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts are presented in Fig. 5 , and their physical properties are presented in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts had similar surface area. And the pore volume decreased with the addition of Sn. It might be ascribed to the small size of Sn4+ blocked the channel of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide. The average pore size of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide also decreased because of Sn-doped reducing the grain size of TiO2 and CeO2 (XRD analysis showed). Moreover, the large number of small diameter holes, which ensuring high specific surface of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide. The isotherms of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts were of Langmuir type IV with an H1 hysteresis loop [19]. However, the relative pressure and hysteresis loop of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts were smaller than Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. The main reason was as follows: on the one hand, the capillary condensation phenomenon of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalyst was enhanced due to the smaller average pore size. On the other hand, the decrease of pore volume also caused the decrease of adsorption. 3.4 Redox property analysis Fig. 6 shows H2-TPR profiles of Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts. All of the Ti-Ce-Ox and Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts exhibit two reduction peaks. As shown in Fig. 6, the first reduction peak of TC appeared at 480°C and the first reduction peak of TSC-3 complex oxide appeared at 320°C, which stand for the reduction of CeO2 (Ce4+ →Ce3+) [20]. Compared to TC catalyst, Sn-doped not only made the reduction peak shifting 160°C to lower temperature but also increased the peak area (from 140831 to 334523, as shown in Table 3 ). It might be attribute to the dispersion of CeO2. And it also demonstrated that Sn-added could inhibit CeO2 enrichment crystallization and increase dispersion of CeO2. The second reduction peak of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst appeared at 650°C. Studies have shown that the pure SnO2 had a reduction peak at 700–760°C [21]. Compared to TC catalyst, Sn4+ added made the reduction peak shifted to higher temperature and also increased peak area significantly (from 568528 to 1426998, as shown in Table 3). With the increase of copper oxide doping amount, the reduction peaks shifted to low temperature direction and the peak area of reduction peaks increased which owing to the hydrogen spill-over effect resulted from the increase of reducible dispersed copper oxide species. When Ti/Sn≥4, the increasing trend was weaken. Additionally, Huang et al. confirmed that the conduction band of SnO2 can enter the band gap of TiO2 and reduce the band gap [22]. This phenomenon can improve redox properties by reducing thermal excitation of electronic transitions required. In a conclusion, compared with Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst, Sn-doped improved redox property significantly. Lietti and Forzatti [23] and Xie et al. [24,25] demonstrated that the surface redox property is the main effective factors in the deNOx activity at low temperature and it is one of the main reasons that tin additives can lead to the active window of the catalyst toward lower temperatures compared to the Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst. 3.5 Surface acid amount and strength The surface acid amount of catalysts were observed by a temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia. The ammonia desorption profiles of the TC and TSC-3 complex oxide catalysts were display in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7, the ammonia desorption of the TC complex oxide catalyst had two peaks: one desorption peak of ammonia appearing at 221°C, which stands for a weak acid position, the other desorption peak of ammonia appearing at 623°C, which stands for a strong acid position. The ammonia desorption of the TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst also proceeded in two stages: one desorption peak of ammonia detected at 260°C, which represented a weak acid position, the desorption peak of ammonia which represented a strong acid position was greater than 800°C. The tin additives led to a shift of the weak acid position and strong acid position towards a higher temperature. Moreover, as shown in Table 4 , the tin additives also increased the peak area of ammonia desorption profile dramatically at the weak acid position and strong acid position. These results indicated that the introduction of tin not only enhance the acid strength but also increase the acid amount of the weak acid site. 3.6 Acid sites Generally, the adsorbed ammonia on catalyst in two types: 1. ammonia adsorbed as stronger molecular adsorbed ammonia on Lewis sites; 2. ammonia adsorbed as ammonium ions on Bronsted acidic hydroxy groups [26]. The Py-IR measurement was used to detecting the type of acid sites. According to the early studies, vibration peaks would be detected at 1450cm−1, when pyridine was adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites of the catalysts. And vibration peaks would be detected at 1540cm−1, when pyridine was adsorbed on the Bronsted [27,28]. Therefore, the acid site types (Lewis acid site or Bronsted acid site) and relative acid amount of the acid sites on the surface of the catalysts were able to distinguish by these two vibration peaks. Fig. 8 shows that Lewis and Bronsted acid sites simultaneously existed on the surface of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst. And, the peak intensity and peak area of Lewis acid sites were bigger than that of Bronsted acid sites. Moreover, the vibration peaks also detected at 1480cm−1. Studies [29] showed that the vibration peaks of 1480cm−1 demonstrate the synergistic effect of Lewis and Bronsted acid sites. When Sn-doped, the main crystal phase of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalyst was SnO2 (XRD analysis showed) and the valence unit of SnO2-CeO2 complex oxide was excess. And the Bronsted acidity was assumed to appear upon the presence of an excess negative charge according to Tanabe's hypothesis. The tin additives not only lead to a significant enhancement of the Lewis sites, but also have effect on the acid amount of the Bronsted acid sites. Fig. 9 shows the Py-IR spectra of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 9, it could be seen that with the increase of temperature, the peak intensity and peak area of Lewis acid sites decreased obviously. It indicated that the Lewis acid sites were more active when at low-temperature. But with the increase of temperature, the decreasing tendency of Bronsted acid sites was relatively weak. In this stage, the Bronsted acid sites were more active. When the temperature completely over 300°C, all the adsorbed NH3 species on Bronsted acid site and Lewis acid site disappear because of decomposition and desorption. Therefore, the Lewis acid sites were more important than Bronsted acid sites at low-temperature. It suggested that enhancement of the Lewis sites was the main reason that the tin additives extended the active temperature window toward lower temperatures. The reaction scheme of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO is shown in Fig. 10 . The reaction process was as follows: NH3 was first adsorbed on the active acid sites and form NH3(ads)/NH4+ (ads), the NH3(ads)/NH4+ (ads) combined with NO and forms NH3 +NO, and then broken down into N2 and H2O [30,31]. 3.7 Micro-morphology The SEM microscopic images of TC and TSC-3 complex oxide catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 . As seen in Fig. 11(a), the micro particles of TC catalyst were crystallization, cluster and agglutination. Furthermore, there was larger gap between clusters and agglutination, indicating that the dispersion of particles was poor. As seen in Fig. 11(b), the micro particles of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst dispersed uniformly. The TEM microscopic images of TC and TSC-3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 10. As seen in Fig. 12 (a), the particle size of Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide was 25–30nm. For the Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide as shown in Fig. 12(b), the particle size decreased obviously (a particle size of 6–8nm is estimated) and the particle also dispersed more uniformly, when introduction of tin. And a closer inspection of the image reveals the existence of smaller crystals dispersed over an amorphous matrix with different contrasts. The solid-phase of catalysts is an important affecting factor for NH3-SCR of NO. As is known, performance is determined by material structure. The result showed that the tin additives could not only refine the particle size, but also but also add amorphous in the solid phase. Generally, the suitable particle sizes, uniformly dispersed particle and amorphous are important affecting factors for NH3-SCR of NO. 3.8 Effect of SO2 and H2O on catalytic activity The anti-sulfur ability and anti-water influence are crucial for SCR catalysts used under the condition of low temperature (<300°C). The SO2 and H2O resistance of the TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst was investigated in this work and the result shown in Fig. 13 . The catalysts were tested at 200°C and under the condition that mol ratio of NH3/NO was 1 and O2 concentration was 6%. As shown in Fig. 13, before injection of SO2 and H2O, the NO conversion efficiency of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst obtained more than 90%. When injecting 300ppm and 10vol.% H2O, the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst decreased rapidly and the highest NO conversion efficiency reduced abruptly about 10–85% at 200°C after 1h. The decrease of NO conversion efficiency attributed to follow reasons: one reason was the competitive adsorption of SO2, water vapor, NO and NH3. The chemisorption of sulfur dioxide and water on the active site, which would inhibit the reaction on acid sites [32,33]; another reason was (NH3)2SO4 and NH4HSO4, which accumulated on the catalyst surface and prevented SCR reaction by blocking active site [34–36]. Fig. 14 illustrates the Fourier infrared spectrum of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst after injecting 300ppm of SO2 gas and 10 vol.% H2O. As seen in Fig. 13, the TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst had vibration peaks which detected at 1127cm−1, 1403cm−1. Studies showed that the vibration peaks of 1403cm−1 and 1127cm−1 stand for vibration spectrum of NH4 + and SO4 2− [34,37,38]. The vibration peaks of the vibration spectrum of NH4 + and SO4 2− indicated that there are a certain amount of sulfates (such as (NH3)2SO4 and NH4HSO4) formed in the surface of catalyst. After injecting SO2 and H2O 1h, the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst fluctuated slightly and kept stable. When cutting off the SO2 and water, the NO conversion efficiency of catalyst recovered gradually, but the highest NO conversion efficiency was lower than original level. Furthermore, the NO conversion efficiency of TSC-3 complex oxide catalyst even reached 85% after injection of SO2 and H2O. It suggested that Sn-doped has improved the anti-sulfur and anti-influence of water vapor performance. Chang et al. also reported that Sn-doped could enhance the anti-sulfur ability and anti-water influence by effectively inhibiting deposition of ammonium salts on the catalyst surface [39]. 4 Conclusions The tin additives extended the active temperature window and lead to the active window of the Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst toward lower temperatures. The NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst reached above 90% at 200°C, when the Ti/Sn (in mol) was equal to 4. Moreover, when injecting 300ppm SO2 and 10 vol.% H2O, the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst was still reached 85% after 25h. In summary, Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalyst not only exhibited the best catalytic performance in the active temperature window of 200–400°C, but also have good anti-sulfur ability and anti-influence of water vapor. The effects of tin additives on structure, acidity and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-Ox as follows: (a) the introduction of tin can refine the particle size, inhibit grain growth of CeO2, TiO2, expand unit cell and cause lattice distortion, which are especially beneficial to NH3-SCR; (b) Sn-doped improved redox property significantly, which lead to active window of the catalyst toward lower temperatures; (c) the tin additives dramatically enhance the acidity of the Lewis sites and Bronsted acid sites, and the enhancement of Lewis sites is the main reason that extended the active temperature window toward lower temperatures. coredata.dc:description: A series of tin-doped Ti-Ce-Ox complex oxide catalysts were synthesized by sol–gel method and tested for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR). Effects of tin additives on structure, acidity and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-Ox for NH3-SCR of NO were investigated through characterization of N2 adsorption–desorption, H2-TPR, XRD, NH3-TPD and SEM. Results showed that tin additives extended the active temperature window especially toward lower temperatures and the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox (the Ti/Sn is equal to 4) catalyst reached 92% at 200°C. The addition of tin not only inhibit grain growth of CeO2 and TiO2, but also expand unit cell and cause lattice distortion, which are especially beneficial to NH3-SCR. Moreover the introduction of tin also improved redox property significantly and enhance the acidity of catalyst. The anti-sulfur and anti-influence of water performance of catalyst also improved by tin-doped, when injecting 300ppm SO2 and 10vol.% H2O, the NO conversion efficiency of Ti-Sn-Ce-Ox catalyst was still reached 85% at 200 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of tin doping level on structure, acidity and catalytic performance of Ti-Ce-Ox catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO by ammonia
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
